content.description:
A mostly bolted route that goes to the top!  

The first half of this route is a little prosaic but the top half weaves through steep corners and faces on good rock.  

Start to the right of econoline and true grit at a black bolt at about 6 meters height.  All pitches are 30-35 meters.

P1-5 are all 30-35 meters in length with difficulties up to 10+ and isn't very distinctive or describable in my opinion.  99% bolted.

P6 Traverse right with lots of bolts.  10-

P7 Climb straight up off the belay through steep edges and jugs trending leftwards to a small stance beneath a good looking corner.  Crux 1.  Thin cams and wires  5.11-.

P8 Follow bolts straight up to the stem box roof contraption, pull on bolts through the roof and belay at a small stance.  Obligatory 10- climbing to the bolt ladder.  This is definitely free-able, probably 12-.

P9 The gem pitch.  Edges and bolts lead to a great stem corner boulder problem crux protected by good cams in blue rock.  Savor the exposure and fun moves to the anchor.  11-

P10 Wander your way through the blue grey runnels.  5.8 fully bolted.  

Scramble up ~100 meters before traversing over to the hikers trail. 

Right end of the multi pitch sport zone.  Black hanger on first bolt, to the left of a lone spruce against the wall.  Check out tabvar for more details.
SIngle rack to 2  with lots of quickdraws and some slings.  All belays are bolted for raps, bail with a 70.

climbs.name: Generosity
climbs.fa: I believe that this route was originally called "Free Fall", and was reworked to become Generosity. FA: Dumerac, Wolfe, Norrie

content.description:
A great route on generally good rock.  The climbing on the water runnels mid-route are fantastic.  The climbing is 5.7-5.8 for the most part, with 3 pitches of 5.9, and many bolts for protection.  There is a picture below of a topo from Im assuming the FA. 

P1: 55m 5.6
P2: 45m 5.7
P3: 50m 5.7
P4: 40m 5.8
P5: 40m 5.6
P6: 40m 5.9
P7: 40m 5.6
P8: 50m 5.9
P9: 50m 5.8
P10 50m 5.7
P11: 55m 5.9
P12: 50m 5.6
P13: 15m 5.5

The route is located past, (NE) of the sport climbs of True Grit and Parallel Dreams.  Hike past those routes for approx. 15mins and across a scree slope.  The trail now enters a treed section, look for a patch of trees against the cliff in a bit of a cave feature. Just past this feature on the right is low angle buttress, the route starts on the right of this.
Standard rack, fixed belays.

Well to the right of the bolted monotony, you will likely find yourself alone for this route.  Generally great climbing on good stone (when it matters) with good belay stances.  Girls Lie is very approachable for the grade.  There's even some good crack climbing! 1) Starting to the left of a shallow cave, climb up easy terrain past a pin to a big ledge.  Belay when appropriate.  5.8 2) Keep moving right, belay at 2 bolts.  5.8 3) Downclimb and traverse towards the attractive corner.  Stem, jam, and cram your way up past bolts and solid gear.  A very good pitch!  2 bolt belay 5.11- 4) Step right off the belay and meander through vague terrain with little gear.  This pitch is a reminder that you're in the Rockies.  Belay at bolts by a large wobbly block, left of an arching crack/choss seem.  5.8 5) Clip a bolt off the belay and continue leftwards following the fault to a feature that leads you up and right to a bolted belay below a steep corner.  5.9 6) Great climbing up the corner (albeit unprotected with belayer-ass-hat potential) to slabby rock above.  Follow bolts and the shallow crack to a nice belay off to the right of the big chimney/trash chute.  Perfect stone!  5.9 7) Make a cool traverse left across the mountain drain to a bolt.  Make bouldery moves up to gain the lower angle rock.  Another great pitch!  Belay at a nice stance with a bolt and wire.  This is the last fixed belay.  5.11- 8) Another alpine-y reminder pitch.  Keep left of the bowl, climbing up to the big ledge.  5.7 Walk left ~60m to a patch of trees, the next pitch begins above a small pine (the highest tree) below two corners.  The remaining pitches are of a different character.   9)It looks improbable but it goes smoothly, though perhaps runout.  Climb the left corner up towards lower angle terrain and a gear belay below steeper rock.  5.8 10) This bit is tough to describe, just aim up and right, gaining the ramp that leads to a shattered ridge feature.  Follow this up and leftwards to a bolt.  Belay here.  5. route-finding dependent. 11) Climb the steep crack above the belay and walk up the tree ridge to a spot below the last steep bit.  5.7 12) ~7m left of the ridge-line is a great crack.  Fists and laybacking past a small roof leads to the ledgey exit climbing.  Belay somewhere.  5.10-   -There is a steeper system directly above the ridge-line, looked very climbable. Continue upwards to a great flat spot.  Channel your inner mountain goat to traverse the filth leftwards to the hikers trail.  It's not as far as it looks, you'll see. About 100 meters right of the McKay Route (the rightmost ramp feature on EEOR as seen from the parking) there is a hanger of the steep yellow stuff, continue under this to a shallow cave.  This cave is to the right of a right-leaning corner that leads to ledges.  You'll know you've got it right if you start up, see a squeeze chimney in the aforementioned corner and say to yourself, "wuh?" and then step right to see a pin, "Ahh Ha."  

If you can still hear climbers further left= haven't gone far enough.  If you've reached the obvious tree ridge= too far. single set to 4. Light on the wires. Double ropes recommended

climbs.name: The Halfpipe
climbs.fa: Adam Campbell, Brandon Pullan in September 2018

content.description:
I first checked the area out in 2007, alone and with a bag full or hardware, and began work ground-up on a nice looking line on the north face of EEOR. After placing eight bolts, I rappelled and could never find a partner willing to head up. My goal was a steep splitter crack in a corner. I later spotted a line on the second buttress of Rundle above the first bowl. Adam Campbell joined me and we made the FAs of this and Homage to the Warden. A great day.

P1: Climb the face following bolts. Place gear in the crack, belay off pitons 5.10a

P2: Straight up the splitter, belay off pitons 5.10b 35m

P3: Up low angle rock to top 5.6



Hike around EEOR and up into the bowl. Crack is easy to spot. Just over 1 hour from car

Single rack to 3

Since this was in the old guidebook and Chris Perry has graciously accepted to share the beta (BUY HIS NEW BOOK, it's excellent! Beautifully made!). Here it is. 
  
 From the old "Banff Rock" Book, (c) Chris Perry: 
  
 This popular, multi-pitch sport route has some excellent climbing although the middle section is relatively easy and lacks interest. The climb is entirely protected by bolts and it makes a good introduction to the longer climbs. It begins up a small rib immediately left of the Fumbles gully and climbs a wide, open corner system in the upper part of the cliff (see photograph in the EEOR section). 
  
 Start on the left-hand side of the scree cone below the Fumbles gully to the right of a small rib. The first pitch is the crux and can be climbed either by moving directly over the bulge or by making a steep move left and down slightly from the bolt to gain good holds that lead up and back right into the scoop above. The latter seems easier for tall climbers and a number of extravagant grades have been assigned to the direct version past the bolt. The second pitch has some excellent slab climbing and leads up to the more broken middle section of the route where some of the pitches may be combined for a faster ascent.  
  
 Pitch 8 is awkward. The third bolt draws the climber too far left around a rib and is best left unclipped, and the crux section in the chimney is far from obvious and the bolts seem misplaced. There is a bolted pitch 9 although the obvious finish is to move left around a rib and wander off up and left on easy ground, as shown in the topo.  
  
 The bolted pitch (5.4) goes straight up above the belay past two bolts and then angles over to the left past two more bolts to a fixed station below easy terrain.  
  
 Extra care is necessary near the top not to dislodge loose rock, particularly using the former finish.  
  
 Descent Use the alternative descent route from EEOR (see next section) that drops down from the ridge and joins the approach trail just below Spud Crag. It is possible to rappel the route with a single 50 m rope but this is not recommended. Not only is the climb often congested with parties trying to make upward progress, but retrieving the rope is likely to generate rockfall.

The left side of the huge gully. You can see the feature from the road.
about 20 QDs and a sport rack. No trad gear required. A 70m rope makes for easy linking

climbs.name: Reprobate
climbs.fa: B. Greenwood, J. Horne, R. Wood & O. Woolcock, 1971. F.F.A.: J. Horne & M. White, 1974

content.description:
Reprobate is an old school classic that winds its way up a large right-facing dihedral on generally solid rock at a sustained 5.7 grade. The crux of the route is a short A0 section (Free: 5.10a or 5.10c if you're short) that can be aided through by pulling on fixed pins or a fixed rope that is often present.. The first two pitches are quite loose, but the belays are well protected.

This climb starts on the prominent 100m high pinnacle that is just a few minutes past where the approach trail meets the wall.
Normal trad rack: cams to 2" and a set of nuts. Belays are bolted or have multiple pins, except the second belay which is one pin and a good nut.

A 6 pitch sport route that climbs incredibly solid and fun rock. Lots of bolts, belay stations every 30m, and acrobatic moves make this a great outing. Every pitch can be linked to make the route only 3 pitches long and have the belays all on comfortable ledges.

The route starts where the approach trail meets the cliffside. Scramble up an easy 15m to the start of the route marked by a two bolt anchor atop a tiny pillar.
14 draws (21 draws if you're linking pitches).

The East End of Rundle (EEOR), commonly referred to as the lackadaisical Winnie the Poor character by locals, hosts a plethora of stellar trad and sport lines on generally excellent grey rock. From single pitch, to huge multi-pitch endeavors, this section of rock boasts a short approach (30-60 minutes) and something for everyone. 
  
 Classics Include: 
 Eeyore's Tail (5.8, 10 pitches) 
 True Grit (5.10a, 6 Pitches) 
 Reprobate (5.7, 11 Pitches) 
 Raptor (5.10b, 9 Pitches) 
 Parallel Dreams (5.11a, 5 Pitches) 
 Geriatric (5.8, 7 Pitches) 
 Generosity (5.9, 13 Pitches)
